ceterms:administrationProcess.ceterms:description: The assessment content is based on input from secondary, post-secondary, and business/industry representatives from the states of Georgia, Michigan, New York, and Pennsylvania.

ceterms:assesses.ceterms:targetNodeName: Identify various body systems, structures, and functions
Recognize abnormal signs and symptoms of disease processes
Demonstrate understanding of confidentiality and HIPAA regulations
Exhibit and identify professional behaviors, resources, and practices of a health assistant
Identify legal and ethical issues in the health assisting field
Demonstrate accurate documentation procedures
Recognize and demonstrate appropriate first aid and emergency techniques
Recognize and demonstrate fire safety and general safety procedures involved in patient care
Recognize and demonstrate appropriate procedures for handling waste and hazardous materials
Recognize signs, symptoms, and reporting mandates for violent or abusive situations
Recognize and demonstrate infection control measures, including standard precautions, hand washing techniques, isolation, and personal protective equipment (PPE)
Differentiate symptoms requiring emergency care
Accurately measure and record vital signs, height, and weight
Demonstrate proper body mechanics, including patient transfer, positioning, lifting, and moving
Assist with elimination needs (e.g., bowel and bladder)
Assist with obtaining body fluid specimens
Assist with personal care and hygiene
Obtain and accurately measure patient intake and output
Assist with patient nutritional needs
Assist with, observe, and report patient skin care conditions
Identify patient chart components (e.g., flowchart, admission, history)
Demonstrate appropriate filing techniques for patient records
Identify and utilize appropriate procedures for cleaning equipment
Identify and interpret word suffixes and prefixes
Identify and interpret word roots
Identify and interpret approved medical abbreviations and acronyms
Identify and differentiate various medical and surgical definitions and conditions
Identify and interpret anatomic terms, including body planes and cavities
Exhibit understanding of healthcare terms
Recognize and practice professional patient and staff communications
Demonstrate accuracy in completing medical forms
Demonstrate proper office skills, telephone technique, and etiquette
Identify and communicate signs and symptoms of major medical conditions
Recognize and respond to cultural diversity
Recognize and provide care for all stages of growth and development

ceterms:assessmentExampleDescription:
The heart and lungs are located in which body cavity?
 A. ventral
 B. cardiac
 C. thoracic
 D. peritoneal
ceterms:deliveryTypeDescription: This assessment is delivered in a web-based delivery system.  Paper-based delivery may be requested.
ceterms:description: This industry-based credential is included in NOCTI’s Job Ready assessment battery. Job Ready assessments measure technical skills at the occupational level and include items which gauge factual and theoretical knowledge.  Job Ready assessments typically offer both a written and performance component and can be used at the secondary and post-secondary levels. Job Ready assessments can be delivered in an online or paper/pencil format.  This assessment can be used at the secondary, post-secondary, and adult levels and is tied to the NOCTI Workforce Competency Credential.  Individuals meeting a minimum benchmark also have the opportunity to earn college credit.  More specific information about the standards and competencies measured can be found in the Assessment Blueprint found at:  http://nocti.org/blueprint.cfm.

ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:description: NOCTI test development/revision committees are convened for each assessment to be developed or revised.  Subject matter experts in the occupational area are recruited.  Subject matter experts must have three years of experience in the occupational area (teaching the occupational area is considered as qualifying experience).  Committees consist of representatives from business/industry and both secondary and post-secondary education.  Geographical representation is also taken into consideration.

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This assessment is available throughout North America.

ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:processFrequency: New development occurs on an as needed basis.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:processMethodDescription:
If a current and complete nationally validated task list is not available for an occupation, a job and task analysis is performed and validated by the committee.  The resulting critical core competencies, tasks and steps are then ranked and quantified to create a blueprint for the assessment being developed.  Once the blueprint is developed, written test questions and performance test jobs are developed or revised to reflect the stated specifications.  Committee members are asked to determine which critical core competencies are best illustrated on the written and performance portions of the test and which can effectively be measured on both components.

NOCTI staff provides each committee member with all appropriate test-related materials.  In addition, all appropriate related supportive curriculum materials as well as item writing guidelines are provided.   Assessments are developed in accordance with the committee’s established blueprint and recommendations.  NOCTI staff provides available relevant test items to the committee members from the NOCTI item bank.

Once the draft test is assembled, a bias review is performed on all items/jobs in the new test and appropriate revisions are made.

Each NOCTI written test is subjected to a readability analysis to ensure the test parallels, but does not exceed, the reading level required in the industry. 

The new assessment is pilot tested on a sample of individuals to ensure times/job criteria on the performance test are appropriate and to determine that items on the written test are functioning properly.  The sample includes representation from various areas of the country.  The results of the pilot tests are compiled and analyzed through an item analysis.  The results of the item analysis indicate item difficulty and discrimination, mean, standard deviation, range of scores, Kuder-Richardson 20 or Cronbach’s Alpha reliability index, and the standard error of measurement.

NOCTI provides clients with a variety of cut score options.  NOCTI provides normative data that may be used as a benchmark as well as criterion-referenced cut scores for each of its job ready assessments.  Clients also have the option of setting their own cut scores on the assessments.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:processStandardsDescription: The Testing Standards are a product of the American Educational Research Association, the American Psychological Association (APA), and the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME). Published collaboratively by the three organizations since 1966, it represents the gold standard in guidance on testing in the United States and in many other countries.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodDescription:
Written assessments consist of a multiple-choice format with four options per item and one correct answer.   Some items may contain graphics that must be referred to in order to answer an item.  Others may provide a scenario to assist in selecting the correct answer.  

Each multiple-choice item is worth one point.  If an individual answers an item correctly, one point is given.  If an individual answers an item incorrectly, no points are given.  All items that are not answered are counted as incorrect.  Scores are calculated by standard area and by total.  Standard scores are determined by dividing the number of questions answered correctly by the number possible within the standard.  Standard scores are considered weighted because each standard does not contain the same number of questions.  Scores are represented by percentages.  A total score is calculated by dividing the total number of questions answered correctly across all standard areas by the total number of points possible across standard areas.

Performance assessments consist of a series of tasks that make up a job. Individuals are required to complete jobs based on instructions provided.  Individual performance is rated by evaluators using specific criteria provided in the assessment’s evaluator guide. The evaluator selects the rating that best defines the work being completed.

Performance scores are based on independent third-party evaluators who are recruited by each of the testing locations.  Each standard within the performance test is considered to be a job. Jobs within the performance assessment consist of tasks normally performed in that occupation. Each task has a point value assigned to it. The point value is determined by the committee of subject matter experts who developed the assessment and indicates the level of criticality of that task. The sum of the point values for each task provides a total number of points possible for a job.  The test taker's methods and adeptness of delivery (process) as well as the finished project (product) are evaluated.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:scoringMethodExampleDescription: NOCTI's standard score report package includes individual, group, and comparative reports. Along with total scores, the sub-scores included in the report assist in easily identifying student and program gains as well as areas for improvement.
ceterms:developmentProcess.ceterms:verificationMethodDescription:
A key strength of all NOCTI assessments concerns content validity. That validity is based upon the fact that each assessment is built upon national/industry standards and reflects the critical core competencies required in the occupation as reflected in associated job-task analyses performed during the development/revision process. Since NOCTI’s assessment development methods rely on subject matter experts to assess the relationship between the assessment content and the defined universe of the job title, NOCTI assessments are a content valid measure of the required skills in a given job title. The Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (2014) state that content-related evidence demonstrates the degree to which the sample of items, tasks, or questions on a test are representative of some defined universe or domain of content. The methods often rely on expert judgments to assess this relationship. Thus, the content validity of NOCTI Assessments is in accordance with the Standards endorsed by the American Educational Research Association (AERA), the American Psychological Association (APA) and the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME).

The reliability of an assessment refers to its consistency of measurement (i.e., the absence of measurement errors). NOCTI works to ensure that all of the assessments that we create have a stable and consistent performance of measurement. One approach used to demonstrate that an assessment is providing a reliable measurement of participant skill and/or knowledge is internal consistency. This measure is often used with written (cognitive) assessments and is calculated using a statistical software package such as SPSS or item analysis programs; NOCTI utilizes both types of programs.  The higher the internal consistency the more reliable the assessment.

Inter-rater reliability for the performance test is assessed by having two evaluators independently score the same individual on the same performance test. If significant differences are determined, the score criteria of the performance test will be re-defined and strengthened to eliminate scoring differences and to ensure inter-rater reliability.

ceterms:instructionalProgramType.ceterms:targetNodeDescription: Any instructional program in allied health and medical assisting services not listed above.
ceterms:instructionalProgramType.ceterms:targetNodeName: Allied Health and Medical Assisting Services, Other

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This credential is available throughout North America.

ceterms:maintenanceProcess.ceterms:description:
Advancements in technology, coupled with changes in occupational practices, result in the need to periodically review and update NOCTI assessments.  Assessments are selected for revision based on a rotation schedule, comments received from users, and on changes in the occupation.  When NOCTI determines that an assessment must be revised, a revision committee is convened with the same representation of content experts as the test development committees.  The revision committee re-evaluates the assessment and changes are made as recommended.  

User comments on assessments are reviewed, sent to subject matter experts if appropriate, and resolved on an ongoing basis.  Minor changes that do not affect the content or scoring rubric of the test are made between revision cycles; major changes are addressed during the revision process which typically occurs every three years.

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This assessment is available throughout North America.

ceterms:maintenanceProcess.ceterms:processFrequency: In general, assessment revision occurs every two to three years.

ceterms:recommends.ceterms:description: NOCTI Study Guides provide a study checklist for each standard on the multiple-choice test  and for all jobs included on the performance test.  Teachers and students can work together to building confidence and knowledge as they prepare for NOCTI testing.

ceterms:estimatedCost.ceterms:description: Study guides are available in packages of 10 or sets of 5.  Each package includes a teacher companion guide and individual student study guides.

ceterms:jurisdiction.ceterms:description: This assessment is available throughout North America.
